Browse the source code of netbsd/sys/external/bsd/drm2/dist/drm/i915/intel_ringbuffer.h

1/* $NetBSD: intel_ringbuffer.h,v 1.6 2018/08/27 07:24:12 riastradh Exp $ */
2
3#ifndef _INTEL_RINGBUFFER_H_
4#define _INTEL_RINGBUFFER_H_
5
6#include <asm/bug.h>
7#include <linux/hashtable.h>
8#include "i915_gem_batch_pool.h"
9
10#define I915_CMD_HASH_ORDER 9
11
12/* Early gen2 devices have a cacheline of just 32 bytes, using 64 is overkill,
13 * but keeps the logic simple. Indeed, the whole purpose of this macro is just
14 * to give some inclination as to some of the magic values used in the various
15 * workarounds!
16 */
17#define CACHELINE_BYTES 64
18#define CACHELINE_DWORDS (CACHELINE_BYTES / sizeof(uint32_t))
19
20/*
21 * Gen2 BSpec "1. Programming Environment" / 1.4.4.6 "Ring Buffer Use"
22 * Gen3 BSpec "vol1c Memory Interface Functions" / 2.3.4.5 "Ring Buffer Use"
23 * Gen4+ BSpec "vol1c Memory Interface and Command Stream" / 5.3.4.5 "Ring Buffer Use"
24 *
25 * "If the Ring Buffer Head Pointer and the Tail Pointer are on the same
26 * cacheline, the Head Pointer must not be greater than the Tail
27 * Pointer."
28 */
29#define I915_RING_FREE_SPACE 64
30
31struct intel_hw_status_page {
32 struct page *page;
33 u32 *page_addr;
34 unsigned int gfx_addr;
35 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
36};
37
38#define I915_READ_TAIL(ring) I915_READ(RING_TAIL((ring)->mmio_base))
39#define I915_WRITE_TAIL(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_TAIL((ring)->mmio_base), val)
40
41#define I915_READ_START(ring) I915_READ(RING_START((ring)->mmio_base))
42#define I915_WRITE_START(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_START((ring)->mmio_base), val)
43
44#define I915_READ_HEAD(ring) I915_READ(RING_HEAD((ring)->mmio_base))
45#define I915_WRITE_HEAD(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_HEAD((ring)->mmio_base), val)
46
47#define I915_READ_CTL(ring) I915_READ(RING_CTL((ring)->mmio_base))
48#define I915_WRITE_CTL(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_CTL((ring)->mmio_base), val)
49
50#define I915_READ_IMR(ring) I915_READ(RING_IMR((ring)->mmio_base))
51#define I915_WRITE_IMR(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_IMR((ring)->mmio_base), val)
52
53#define I915_READ_MODE(ring) I915_READ(RING_MI_MODE((ring)->mmio_base))
54#define I915_WRITE_MODE(ring, val) I915_WRITE(RING_MI_MODE((ring)->mmio_base), val)
55
56/* seqno size is actually only a uint32, but since we plan to use MI_FLUSH_DW to
57 * do the writes, and that must have qw aligned offsets, simply pretend it's 8b.
58 */
59#define i915_semaphore_seqno_size sizeof(uint64_t)
60#define GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(__ring, to) \
61 (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_offset(dev_priv->semaphore_obj) + \
62 ((__ring)->id * I915_NUM_RINGS * i915_semaphore_seqno_size) + \
63 (i915_semaphore_seqno_size * (to)))
64
65#define GEN8_WAIT_OFFSET(__ring, from) \
66 (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_offset(dev_priv->semaphore_obj) + \
67 ((from) * I915_NUM_RINGS * i915_semaphore_seqno_size) + \
68 (i915_semaphore_seqno_size * (__ring)->id))
69
70#define GEN8_RING_SEMAPHORE_INIT do { \
71 if (!dev_priv->semaphore_obj) { \
72 break; \
73 } \
74 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[RCS] = GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(ring, RCS); \
75 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[VCS] = GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(ring, VCS); \
76 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[BCS] = GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(ring, BCS); \
77 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[VECS] = GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(ring, VECS); \
78 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[VCS2] = GEN8_SIGNAL_OFFSET(ring, VCS2); \
79 ring->semaphore.signal_ggtt[ring->id] = MI_SEMAPHORE_SYNC_INVALID; \
80 } while(0)
81
82enum intel_ring_hangcheck_action {
83 HANGCHECK_IDLE = 0,
84 HANGCHECK_WAIT,
85 HANGCHECK_ACTIVE,
86 HANGCHECK_ACTIVE_LOOP,
87 HANGCHECK_KICK,
88 HANGCHECK_HUNG,
89};
90
91#define HANGCHECK_SCORE_RING_HUNG 31
92
93struct intel_ring_hangcheck {
94 u64 acthd;
95 u64 max_acthd;
96 u32 seqno;
97 int score;
98 enum intel_ring_hangcheck_action action;
99 int deadlock;
100};
101
102struct intel_ringbuffer {
103 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
104#ifdef __NetBSD__
105 bus_space_tag_t bst;
106 bus_space_handle_t bsh;
107#else
108 void __iomem *virtual_start;
109#endif
110
111 struct intel_engine_cs *ring;
112
113 u32 head;
114 u32 tail;
115 int space;
116 int size;
117 int effective_size;
118 int reserved_size;
119 int reserved_tail;
120 bool reserved_in_use;
121
122 /** We track the position of the requests in the ring buffer, and
123 * when each is retired we increment last_retired_head as the GPU
124 * must have finished processing the request and so we know we
125 * can advance the ringbuffer up to that position.
126 *
127 * last_retired_head is set to -1 after the value is consumed so
128 * we can detect new retirements.
129 */
130 u32 last_retired_head;
131};
132
133struct intel_context;
134struct drm_i915_reg_descriptor;
135
136/*
137 * we use a single page to load ctx workarounds so all of these
138 * values are referred in terms of dwords
139 *
140 * struct i915_wa_ctx_bb:
141 * offset: specifies batch starting position, also helpful in case
142 * if we want to have multiple batches at different offsets based on
143 * some criteria. It is not a requirement at the moment but provides
144 * an option for future use.
145 * size: size of the batch in DWORDS
146 */
147struct i915_ctx_workarounds {
148 struct i915_wa_ctx_bb {
149 u32 offset;
150 u32 size;
151 } indirect_ctx, per_ctx;
152 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
153};
154
155struct intel_engine_cs {
156 const char *name;
157 enum intel_ring_id {
158 RCS = 0x0,
159 VCS,
160 BCS,
161 VECS,
162 VCS2
163 } id;
164#define I915_NUM_RINGS 5
165#define LAST_USER_RING (VECS + 1)
166 u32 mmio_base;
167 struct drm_device *dev;
168 struct intel_ringbuffer *buffer;
169
170 /*
171 * A pool of objects to use as shadow copies of client batch buffers
172 * when the command parser is enabled. Prevents the client from
173 * modifying the batch contents after software parsing.
174 */
175 struct i915_gem_batch_pool batch_pool;
176
177 struct intel_hw_status_page status_page;
178 struct i915_ctx_workarounds wa_ctx;
179
180 unsigned irq_refcount; /* protected by dev_priv->irq_lock */
181 u32 irq_enable_mask; /* bitmask to enable ring interrupt */
182 struct drm_i915_gem_request *trace_irq_req;
183 bool __must_check (*irq_get)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
184 void (*irq_put)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
185
186 int (*init_hw)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
187
188 int (*init_context)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
189
190 void (*write_tail)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
191 u32 value);
192 int __must_check (*flush)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req,
193 u32 invalidate_domains,
194 u32 flush_domains);
195 int (*add_request)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
196 /* Some chipsets are not quite as coherent as advertised and need
197 * an expensive kick to force a true read of the up-to-date seqno.
198 * However, the up-to-date seqno is not always required and the last
199 * seen value is good enough. Note that the seqno will always be
200 * monotonic, even if not coherent.
201 */
202 u32 (*get_seqno)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
203 bool lazy_coherency);
204 void (*set_seqno)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
205 u32 seqno);
206 int (*dispatch_execbuffer)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req,
207 u64 offset, u32 length,
208 unsigned dispatch_flags);
209#define I915_DISPATCH_SECURE 0x1
210#define I915_DISPATCH_PINNED 0x2
211#define I915_DISPATCH_RS 0x4
212 void (*cleanup)(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
213
214 /* GEN8 signal/wait table - never trust comments!
215 * signal to signal to signal to signal to signal to
216 * RCS VCS BCS VECS VCS2
217 * --------------------------------------------------------------------
218 * RCS | NOP (0x00) | VCS (0x08) | BCS (0x10) | VECS (0x18) | VCS2 (0x20) |
219 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
220 * VCS | RCS (0x28) | NOP (0x30) | BCS (0x38) | VECS (0x40) | VCS2 (0x48) |
221 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
222 * BCS | RCS (0x50) | VCS (0x58) | NOP (0x60) | VECS (0x68) | VCS2 (0x70) |
223 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
224 * VECS | RCS (0x78) | VCS (0x80) | BCS (0x88) | NOP (0x90) | VCS2 (0x98) |
225 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
226 * VCS2 | RCS (0xa0) | VCS (0xa8) | BCS (0xb0) | VECS (0xb8) | NOP (0xc0) |
227 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
228 *
229 * Generalization:
230 * f(x, y) := (x->id * NUM_RINGS * seqno_size) + (seqno_size * y->id)
231 * ie. transpose of g(x, y)
232 *
233 * sync from sync from sync from sync from sync from
234 * RCS VCS BCS VECS VCS2
235 * --------------------------------------------------------------------
236 * RCS | NOP (0x00) | VCS (0x28) | BCS (0x50) | VECS (0x78) | VCS2 (0xa0) |
237 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
238 * VCS | RCS (0x08) | NOP (0x30) | BCS (0x58) | VECS (0x80) | VCS2 (0xa8) |
239 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
240 * BCS | RCS (0x10) | VCS (0x38) | NOP (0x60) | VECS (0x88) | VCS2 (0xb0) |
241 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
242 * VECS | RCS (0x18) | VCS (0x40) | BCS (0x68) | NOP (0x90) | VCS2 (0xb8) |
243 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
244 * VCS2 | RCS (0x20) | VCS (0x48) | BCS (0x70) | VECS (0x98) | NOP (0xc0) |
245 * |-------------------------------------------------------------------
246 *
247 * Generalization:
248 * g(x, y) := (y->id * NUM_RINGS * seqno_size) + (seqno_size * x->id)
249 * ie. transpose of f(x, y)
250 */
251 struct {
252 u32 sync_seqno[I915_NUM_RINGS-1];
253
254 union {
255 struct {
256 /* our mbox written by others */
257 u32 wait[I915_NUM_RINGS];
258 /* mboxes this ring signals to */
259 u32 signal[I915_NUM_RINGS];
260 } mbox;
261 u64 signal_ggtt[I915_NUM_RINGS];
262 };
263
264 /* AKA wait() */
265 int (*sync_to)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *to_req,
266 struct intel_engine_cs *from,
267 u32 seqno);
268 int (*signal)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *signaller_req,
269 /* num_dwords needed by caller */
270 unsigned int num_dwords);
271 } semaphore;
272
273 /* Execlists */
274 spinlock_t execlist_lock;
275 struct list_head execlist_queue;
276 struct list_head execlist_retired_req_list;
277 u8 next_context_status_buffer;
278 u32 irq_keep_mask; /* bitmask for interrupts that should not be masked */
279 int (*emit_request)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *request);
280 int (*emit_flush)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *request,
281 u32 invalidate_domains,
282 u32 flush_domains);
283 int (*emit_bb_start)(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req,
284 u64 offset, unsigned dispatch_flags);
285
286 /**
287 * List of objects currently involved in rendering from the
288 * ringbuffer.
289 *
290 * Includes buffers having the contents of their GPU caches
291 * flushed, not necessarily primitives. last_read_req
292 * represents when the rendering involved will be completed.
293 *
294 * A reference is held on the buffer while on this list.
295 */
296 struct list_head active_list;
297
298 /**
299 * List of breadcrumbs associated with GPU requests currently
300 * outstanding.
301 */
302 struct list_head request_list;
303
304 /**
305 * Seqno of request most recently submitted to request_list.
306 * Used exclusively by hang checker to avoid grabbing lock while
307 * inspecting request list.
308 */
309 u32 last_submitted_seqno;
310
311 bool gpu_caches_dirty;
312
313#ifdef __NetBSD__
314 drm_waitqueue_t irq_queue;
315#else
316 wait_queue_head_t irq_queue;
317#endif
318
319 struct intel_context *default_context;
320 struct intel_context *last_context;
321
322 struct intel_ring_hangcheck hangcheck;
323
324 struct {
325 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
326 u32 gtt_offset;
327 volatile u32 *cpu_page;
328 } scratch;
329
330 bool needs_cmd_parser;
331
332 /*
333 * Table of commands the command parser needs to know about
334 * for this ring.
335 */
336 DECLARE_HASHTABLE(cmd_hash, I915_CMD_HASH_ORDER);
337
338 /*
339 * Table of registers allowed in commands that read/write registers.
340 */
341 const struct drm_i915_reg_descriptor *reg_table;
342 int reg_count;
343
344 /*
345 * Table of registers allowed in commands that read/write registers, but
346 * only from the DRM master.
347 */
348 const struct drm_i915_reg_descriptor *master_reg_table;
349 int master_reg_count;
350
351 /*
352 * Returns the bitmask for the length field of the specified command.
353 * Return 0 for an unrecognized/invalid command.
354 *
355 * If the command parser finds an entry for a command in the ring's
356 * cmd_tables, it gets the command's length based on the table entry.
357 * If not, it calls this function to determine the per-ring length field
358 * encoding for the command (i.e. certain opcode ranges use certain bits
359 * to encode the command length in the header).
360 */
361 u32 (*get_cmd_length_mask)(u32 cmd_header);
362};
363
364bool intel_ring_initialized(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
365
366static inline unsigned
367intel_ring_flag(struct intel_engine_cs *ring)
368{
369 return 1 << ring->id;
370}
371
372static inline u32
373intel_ring_sync_index(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
374 struct intel_engine_cs *other)
375{
376 int idx;
377
378 /*
379 * rcs -> 0 = vcs, 1 = bcs, 2 = vecs, 3 = vcs2;
380 * vcs -> 0 = bcs, 1 = vecs, 2 = vcs2, 3 = rcs;
381 * bcs -> 0 = vecs, 1 = vcs2. 2 = rcs, 3 = vcs;
382 * vecs -> 0 = vcs2, 1 = rcs, 2 = vcs, 3 = bcs;
383 * vcs2 -> 0 = rcs, 1 = vcs, 2 = bcs, 3 = vecs;
384 */
385
386 idx = (other - ring) - 1;
387 if (idx < 0)
388 idx += I915_NUM_RINGS;
389
390 return idx;
391}
392
393static inline void
394intel_flush_status_page(struct intel_engine_cs *ring, int reg)
395{
396 drm_clflush_virt_range(&ring->status_page.page_addr[reg],
397 sizeof(uint32_t));
398}
399
400static inline u32
401intel_read_status_page(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
402 int reg)
403{
404 /* Ensure that the compiler doesn't optimize away the load. */
405 barrier();
406 return ring->status_page.page_addr[reg];
407}
408
409static inline void
410intel_write_status_page(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
411 int reg, u32 value)
412{
413 ring->status_page.page_addr[reg] = value;
414}
415
416/**
417 * Reads a dword out of the status page, which is written to from the command
418 * queue by automatic updates, MI_REPORT_HEAD, MI_STORE_DATA_INDEX, or
419 * MI_STORE_DATA_IMM.
420 *
421 * The following dwords have a reserved meaning:
422 * 0x00: ISR copy, updated when an ISR bit not set in the HWSTAM changes.
423 * 0x04: ring 0 head pointer
424 * 0x05: ring 1 head pointer (915-class)
425 * 0x06: ring 2 head pointer (915-class)
426 * 0x10-0x1b: Context status DWords (GM45)
427 * 0x1f: Last written status offset. (GM45)
428 * 0x20-0x2f: Reserved (Gen6+)
429 *
430 * The area from dword 0x30 to 0x3ff is available for driver usage.
431 */
432#define I915_GEM_HWS_INDEX 0x30
433#define I915_GEM_HWS_SCRATCH_INDEX 0x40
434#define I915_GEM_HWS_SCRATCH_ADDR (I915_GEM_HWS_SCRATCH_INDEX << MI_STORE_DWORD_INDEX_SHIFT)
435
436struct intel_ringbuffer *
437intel_engine_create_ringbuffer(struct intel_engine_cs *engine, int size);
438int intel_pin_and_map_ringbuffer_obj(struct drm_device *dev,
439 struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
440void intel_unpin_ringbuffer_obj(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
441void intel_ringbuffer_free(struct intel_ringbuffer *ring);
442
443void intel_stop_ring_buffer(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
444void intel_cleanup_ring_buffer(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
445
446int intel_ring_alloc_request_extras(struct drm_i915_gem_request *request);
447
448int __must_check intel_ring_begin(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req, int n);
449int __must_check intel_ring_cacheline_align(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
450static inline void intel_ring_emit(struct intel_engine_cs *ring,
451 u32 data)
452{
453 struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf = ring->buffer;
454#ifdef __NetBSD__
455 bus_space_write_4(ringbuf->bst, ringbuf->bsh, ringbuf->tail, data);
456#else
457 iowrite32(data, ringbuf->virtual_start + ringbuf->tail);
458#endif
459 ringbuf->tail += 4;
460}
461static inline void intel_ring_advance(struct intel_engine_cs *ring)
462{
463 struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf = ring->buffer;
464 ringbuf->tail &= ringbuf->size - 1;
465}
466int __intel_ring_space(int head, int tail, int size);
467void intel_ring_update_space(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
468int intel_ring_space(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
469bool intel_ring_stopped(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
470
471int __must_check intel_ring_idle(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
472void intel_ring_init_seqno(struct intel_engine_cs *ring, u32 seqno);
473int intel_ring_flush_all_caches(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
474int intel_ring_invalidate_all_caches(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
475
476void intel_fini_pipe_control(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
477int intel_init_pipe_control(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
478
479int intel_init_render_ring_buffer(struct drm_device *dev);
480int intel_init_bsd_ring_buffer(struct drm_device *dev);
481int intel_init_bsd2_ring_buffer(struct drm_device *dev);
482int intel_init_blt_ring_buffer(struct drm_device *dev);
483int intel_init_vebox_ring_buffer(struct drm_device *dev);
484
485u64 intel_ring_get_active_head(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
486
487int init_workarounds_ring(struct intel_engine_cs *ring);
488
489static inline u32 intel_ring_get_tail(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf)
490{
491 return ringbuf->tail;
492}
493
494/*
495 * Arbitrary size for largest possible 'add request' sequence. The code paths
496 * are complex and variable. Empirical measurement shows that the worst case
497 * is ILK at 136 words. Reserving too much is better than reserving too little
498 * as that allows for corner cases that might have been missed. So the figure
499 * has been rounded up to 160 words.
500 */
501#define MIN_SPACE_FOR_ADD_REQUEST 160
502
503/*
504 * Reserve space in the ring to guarantee that the i915_add_request() call
505 * will always have sufficient room to do its stuff. The request creation
506 * code calls this automatically.
507 */
508void intel_ring_reserved_space_reserve(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf, int size);
509/* Cancel the reservation, e.g. because the request is being discarded. */
510void intel_ring_reserved_space_cancel(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
511/* Use the reserved space - for use by i915_add_request() only. */
512void intel_ring_reserved_space_use(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
513/* Finish with the reserved space - for use by i915_add_request() only. */
514void intel_ring_reserved_space_end(struct intel_ringbuffer *ringbuf);
515
516/* Legacy ringbuffer specific portion of reservation code: */
517int intel_ring_reserve_space(struct drm_i915_gem_request *request);
518
519#endif /* _INTEL_RINGBUFFER_H_ */
